description.plain:
Cypress Hill is an West Coast – Cuban-American/Latino hip hop group originated from South Gate, California.
Members of the group: B-Real, Muggs, Sen Dog, Eric Bobo.
Past member of Cypress Hill was Mellow Man Ace.



Discography

1991: Cypress Hill
1992: Something for the Blunted
1993: Black Sunday
1995: Cypress Hill III: Temples of Boom
1996: Unreleased & Revamped
1998: Cypress Hill IV
1999: Los Grandes Éxitos en Español
2000: Skull & Bones
2001: Stoned Riders
2002: Stash
2004: Till Death Do Us Part
2004: Smoke ‘Em If You Got 'Em
2010: Rise Up
2012: Cypress x Rusko
2018: Elephants On Acid

songs.full_title: Insane in the Brain by Cypress Hill
songs.title: Insane in the Brain

description.plain:
According to B-Real, the song was actually a diss song aimed at Chubb Rock. The group felt Chubb had ridiculed their style on his 1992 album I Gotta Get Mine Yo.

It is claimed that DJ Muggs produced the song “Jump Around” by House of Pain, which was later used to produce this song, with minor changes.

The song is built around many samples: a repeating sample of a horse from Mel and Tim’s “Good Guys Only Win in the Movies”; a drum break from organist George Semper’s cover version of Lee Dorsey’s “Get Out of My Life, Woman”; a sample of James Brown grunting from the opening of his song “Say It Loud – I’m Black and I’m Proud”; a sample of the line “insane in the brain” from Cypress Hill’s own song “Hole in the Head”; the opening keyboard from Sly & the Family Stone’s “Life” and a sample of the line “I think I’m going crazy” from The Youngbloods' “All Over the World (La La),” which concludes the track. In 2007, it was ranked number 85 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of the 90s.

According to a live interview aired on Double J during a feature of the Black Sunday album, ‘insane in the membrane’ was a localised gang term used at the time by the Crips when doing something crazy. It was then appropriated into this song. The interview also notes that B-Real was a member of the Bloods.

songs.full_title: How I Could Just Kill a Man by Cypress Hill
songs.title: How I Could Just Kill a Man
songs.title_with_featured: How I Could Just Kill a Man

description.plain:
Cypress Hill’s debut single and first big hit. “How I Could Just Kill A Man” was actually the b-side of the single but it quickly overshadowed its a-side, “The Phuncky Feel One”.

The video, featuring the group strolling around New York City, was released after the song had become a hit (presumably with a much lower budget than the cool, arty video for “Phuncky Feel One”). It has cameos from Ice Cube and Q-Tip.

In 1999, Cypress released a Spanish version of the song, “No Entiendes La Onda”.

songs.full_title: I Wanna Get High by Cypress Hill
songs.title: I Wanna Get High

description.plain:
Artist: Cypress Hill
Album: Black Sunday
Released: July 20, 1993
Recorded: 1992
Genre: West Coast Hip Hop
Label: Ruffhouse, Columbia
Producer: Muggs, T-Ray



PRODUCING

The producers of the song are DJ Muggs and T-Ray.
At the song there are parts from “Hits From The Bong”, which it’s also a Cypress Hill’s and T-Ray’s mix.

SAMPLES

The intro and outro (throughout) at 0:20 is a sample used by Junior Parker – Taxman.
At  Junior’s song, the sample appears at 0:04.
There two another different samples, 1. Hits From The Bong is actually a sample by Cypress Hill “Hits From the Bong”, the 2nd one “I Wanna Get High, So High”, is a sample of Rita Marley’s song “One Draw”.

CONTRIBUTIONS

Cypress Hill also contributed a track “I Wanna Get High” to the High Times sponsored Hempilation album to support NORML.

MOVIES

The song is also featured in How High movie starring Method Man & Redman.
Same goes for the songs “Hits From the Bong” and “Cisco Kid” featuring again Method Man and Redman.

description.plain:
“(Rock) Superstar” peaked at #18 on Billboard’s Modern Rock chart.



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4VpE-0zitU

“Rock superstar” may have a double meaning, in that “rock” is both a form of music and a form of cocaine.  Some of the warnings in the song could apply to the life of a drug dealer as well as a musician.

songs.title: Lowrider

description.plain: “Lowrider” is the second single by Cypress Hill from the album Stoned Raiders. The song is featured in the British TV series Soccer AM. The song was the second part of the double A-Side single it shared with “Trouble” in Europe. “Lowrider” was not released until February elsewhere.

songs.full_title: Hand on the Pump by Cypress Hill
songs.title: Hand on the Pump

description.plain:
Early single by Cypress Hill off their first album.  The song introduced the line “sawed off shotgun, hand on the pump” into the Hip Hop lexicon.  The song prominantly samples Gene Chandler’s early 60’s doo-wop hit “Duke of Earl.”




Here’s a video version for those who can’t listen to the youtube link (in germany for example):

http://vimeo.com/62995038

songs.full_title: I Ain't Goin' Out Like That by Cypress Hill
songs.title: I Ain’t Goin’ Out Like That
songs.title_with_featured: I Ain't Goin' Out Like That

description.plain:
After the hook this song samples the intro to “The Wizard” by Black Sabbath. The group were also banned from Saturday Night Live after they performed this song because DJ Muggs lit up a blunt on stage and they trashed the set after.

In an interview with The Village Voice in 2014, Sen Dog recounted the night, saying:

Well, there’s a lot of stories behind why Muggs lit that joint. I remember Saturday Night Live gave us a greenroom and said, “Do whatever you want in here, just don’t light up out of here.” Muggs felt like he needed to make a statement with his performance. It wasn’t just the Saturday Night Live people saying he couldn’t smoke up on air. It was everyone: our record label, our management, our friends. I felt like, to me, Muggs wanted to make that statement. He asked me to light the joint up on stage, and I said, “I’m not doing that, man.” Before we did that second song, we agreed that we weren’t going to light up nothing. If you look, I was surprised that he did that. People loved it — people at the show loved it, because at the after-party they said, “That was so cool.” But when the hammer swung and we were banned from Saturday Night Live forever, we understood how serious it was. And understandably so — the world wasn’t ready for anything near that at that time. If he did it now, I don’t know what kind of backlash he’d have, but in the early ’90s, it earned us a kick in the ass from Saturday Night Live, and I haven’t seen that episode in reruns. It would have been cool to do Saturday Night Live again, but me personally, I didn’t think it was a great thing to do for our first time on SNL, but we paid the price and we moved on.

Watch a video of their performance on SNL here:

https://youtu.be/TdTChS-Ct88

description.plain:
“Throwing your set in the air” refers to performing a hand signal or a series of hand signals to indicate what “set,” or gang subsidiary, you belong to. Cypress Hill members Sen Dog, Mellow Man Ace, and B-Real belong to the “Neighborhood Family” set within the Bloods.

http://youtu.be/_7CvttRtnYM?t=24s

The song is about the commitment, violence, and mentality involved in joining and belonging to a set.

It’s also the song that Ice Cube partially stole from for his own song Friday, off the soundtrack to the movie by the same name.

Oh yeah, throw ya neighborhood in tha air
  If ya don’t care

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LTgBBf1C_tI

songs.full_title: Armada Latina by Cypress Hill (Ft. Marc Anthony & Pitbull)
songs.title: Armada Latina

description.plain:
On “Armada Latina”, Cypress Hill, the first big Cuban-American hip-hop act (and the first big Latino hip-hop act for that matter) get together with Pitbull, the most prominent Latino in hip-hop of his generation, who happens to also be Cuban-American and Marc Anthony, a Puerto Rican-American, who sings the hook. It heavily samples the Crosby Stills & Nash song “Suite: Judy Blue Eyes”.

The song almost appeared on the US pop chart, reaching #6 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 Chart in early 2010.

The 13th track of the old-school album Cypress Hill by Cypress Hill, released August 13, 1991



Latin Lingo show just how great diversity the English language can have when a little Spanish is added; giving it the term “Spanglish”.

songs.lyrics:

[B-Real]

In clothes exploiting her body from head to toes
She had glossy lips she was swaying her hips

Trying to impress her in vain she gave no play
Niggas hit her up for numbers and she said no way
I thought to myself let it go and roll on, B
But like Smokey said she really had a hold on me
I couldn't stop staring I started to fantasize with her
Voices in my head said she's tantalizing ya
Even if I moved to the other side of the party
I had pictures in my head of her moving that body
I was beside myself with hunger pain
So I slowly walked over and I asked her name

[Hook: repeat 2X]
What's your name, what's your number?
I would like to get to know you
Can we have a conversation?
The night is young, girl give me a chance!

[B-Real]

I offered her a drink she turned me down flat
She said if you want my name you gotta do better than that
I said OK, now your shit don't stink
I'ma walk away only tried to buy you a drink

But every guy in the club tried slipping me pills
I don't trust guys each and every one will lie to you
I said I understand but it's not what I try to do

I go after what I want but I got class
For me no need to slip a pill if I want ass

She let her guard down and on our conversation went

[Hook]

[B-Real]

I'm too good for that I have so much to offer
Got a good job working at my mom and dad's law firm
You got goals, that's what she asked
Yeah I wanna fill my home with platinum plaques
It takes hard work but you know it's coming after
She said 'oh my God you must be a famous rapper!'
I do all right but I'm never satisfied
I'm told when you still love what you do it never gets old
I strive for more but that's enough about me

description.plain:
This is the opening track off of Cypress Hill’s self-titled first album.

Cypress Hill break down the different types of corrupt law enforcement, and what eventually happens to the ones who get caught and put to jail.

One of the more underrated songs about police.

songs.full_title: Locotes by Cypress Hill
songs.title: Locotes

description.plain:
This is a song that describes typical characters from Cypress Hill imaginery. Two guys, maybe from a gang, have came out of jail. They have got a new job stealing things. They are walking down the city to see what they can steal. They spot a couple of guys with stuff to steal from them. So they do. However, the police is chasing them. They run away in a car, that eventually is left abandoned by them.  While approaching to the empty vehicle, one police officer gets shot by the two characters. They run away from the crime scene and get on a bus, happy for having escaped. However, when trying to take advantage of a drunk white male on the bus, the latter takes out a pistol and shoots one of the characters to death.

It’s the law of the street: sometimes you win, sometimes you loose.

Stoned is the Way of the Walk
Stoned is the Way of the Walk
Stoned is the Way of the Walk
Stoned is the Way of the Walk

[Outro: Sen Dog]
Hit they ass, hit they ass

[B-Real]
Like the buddha that's stinky

(Alas, Cap'in there's a ship in sight)
